The purpose of this vignette is to explain which colors and color palettes exist in `unikn` and how to use them.


## Overview 

Please load the `unikn` package to get started: 

```{r load_pkg, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
library(unikn)  # load unikn package
```

There are two functions to interact with the color palettes in the `unikn` package:  `seecol` and `usecol`

The function `seecol` is a general-purpose tool for viewing (or _seeing_) color palettes. 
`seecol` takes 2 main arguments:

1. `pal` describes either 1 or multiple color palettes (with a default `p = "all"`)
2. `n` describes the number of desired colors (with a default `n = "all"`).

Based on the setting of `pal`, the `seecol` function distinguishes between 2 modes: 

* _comparing_ a set of color palettes by passing a keyword or `list`-object
* viewing _details_ of a single color palette 

`usecol` allows you to use a color palette without showing the color palette 


## Viewing and comparing available color palettes with `seecol` 

When the `pal` argument specifies (a list of) multiple color palettes, `seecol` plots a vector for each palette to allow comparing these palettes. 
Some special keywords within the `unikn` package are `"unikn_all"`, `"unikn_basic"`, `pair_all"`, `"pref_all"` and `"grad_all"`.  They allow comparing predefined sets of the color palettes within the `unikn`-package.  

Viewing _all_ available color palettes:

```{r seecol_unikn_all, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 6}
seecol("unikn_all")  # same as seecol("all")
```

1. three _basic_ color palettes:

```{r seecol_unikn_basic_2, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 2.5}
seecol("unikn_basic")
```

Note, that `pal_unikn_web` and `pal_unikn_ppt` are almost identical, but differ in how vibrant their colors are.  

2. three _paired_ color palettes:

```{r seecol_pair_all, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 2.5}
seecol("pair_all")
```

3. all _preferred_ colors from the spectrum and their respective _gradients_:

```{r seecol_pref_all, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 4}
seecol("pref_all")
```

4. only the pre-defined color _gradients_:

```{r seecol_grad_all_2, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 3.5}
seecol("grad_all")
```


## Viewing and saving a palette with `seecol` 

When the `pal` argument specifies a single color palette, `seecol` plots a more detailed view of this particular color palette: 

```{r unikn_palette, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
seecol(pal_unikn)  # view details of pal_unikn
```

You can _see_ 

* the color names 
* indices in the color palette 
* the hex values of each color 
* the RGB values for each color 

A typical workflow may include _seeing_ a color palette, saving it, and using it in a plot.  

```{r save_seecol, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
mypal <- seecol(pal_unikn_light)  # view details of AND save pal_unikn_light to mypal  
```

After saving the color palette you can use the palette object in your plot: 


```{r mypal_example, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
barplot(1/sqrt(1:10), col = mypal)  # use mypal in a plot
```

Note that `seecol` _invisibly_ returns the color palette.  
Thus, the following will only plot the palette without doing anything else with the color vector:

```{r invisible_seecol, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
seecol(pal_bordeaux)
```

## Using a palette with `usecol` (without seeing it)

The `usecol` function allows directly using a color palette in a plot (i.e., without first viewing it).
`usecol` corresponds to `seecol` by taking the same 2 main arguments (`pal` and `n`). 
However, as its purpose is _using_ the colors specified by `pal`, rather than plotting (or _seeing_) them, the `pal` argument typically contains only one color palette. 

```{r use_col_default_use, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
# Using a color palette:
barplot(1/sqrt(1:11), col = usecol(pal_unikn))
```

Note that the both the `seecol` and the `usecol` function are quite permissive with respect to specifying their `pal` argument: 
A particular color palette (e.g., `pal_seegruen`) can not only be displayed by providing it (as an object) but also by providing its name (i.e., `"pal_seegruen"`) or even its incomplete object name or name (i.e., `"seegruen"` or `seegruen`). 
Hence, the following all yield the same result: 

```{r free_pal_args, eval = FALSE}
seecol(pal_seegruen)
seecol("pal_seegruen")
seecol(seegruen)  # issues a warning
seecol("seegruen")
```


## Customizing color palettes

Both `seecol` and `usecol` allow a flexible on-the-fly customization of color palettes.  

Specifying a value for the `n` argument of `seecol` an `usecol` allows you to 

* specify a subset of colors and compare these subsets for different palettes for `n` _smaller_ than the length of the color palette. 
* extend a color palette and compare different palettes for `n` _greater_ than the length of the color palette. 

Finally, passing a vector of colors and/or color palettes allows you creating and viewing your own palettes. 

### Selecting subsets

Using only a subset of colors:

```{r use_subset, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 6}
seecol("unikn_all", n = 4)
seecol(pal_unikn, 4)
```

Importantly, when using pre-defined color palettes of `unikn` but a value of `n` that is smaller than the length of the current color palette, `usecol` and `seecol` select a predefined subset of colors:

```{r use_col_smalln, fig.height = 5}
barplot(1/sqrt(1:2), col = usecol(pal_seeblau, n = 2))
barplot(1/sqrt(1:3), col = usecol(pal_seeblau, n = 3))
```

### Extending color palettes

For values of `n` that are larger than the number of available colors in `pal`, the specified color palette is extended using `ColorRampPalette`:

```{r use_superset, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 6}
seecol("all", n = 12)
seecol(pal_seeblau, 12)
```

When using a color palette: 

```{r use_col_big_n, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
barplot(1/sqrt(1:11), col = usecol(pal_bordeaux, n = 11))
```

### Mixing color palettes

By passing a vector, as in the example below, you can for instance concatenate two palettes and connect them with white as the midpoint.  

```{r combine_pals, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
seecol(pal = c(rev(pal_petrol), "white", pal_bordeaux))
```

You can also combine a set of colors and extend this palette by specifying an `n` argument greater than the length of your specified palette. 

```{r combine_pals_n, fig.width = 7, fig.asp = .618}
seecol(pal = usecol(c(Karpfenblau, Seeblau, "gold"), n = 10))  
# Note, that redundant use of seecol and usecol shows HEX values as names.
# seecol(pal = c(Karpfenblau, Seeblau, "gold"), n = 10)  # would work, but show no intermediate names
```

These custom palettes you can easily use in a plot.  Here, we define and use a subset of the `pal_unikn_pair` palette: 

```{r use_mypair, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 4}
mypair <- seecol(pal_unikn_pair, n = 10)

## Create some data: 
dat <- matrix(sample(5:10, size = 10, replace = TRUE), ncol = 5)
barplot(dat, beside = TRUE, col = mypair)
```

### Comparing custom palettes 

Sometimes you may want to compare a palette you created to your other or the existing palettes.  Therefore, advanced users can also use `seecol` for displaying and comparing different custom palettes. Seecol will output a _comparison_ of the inputs if you specify the `pal` argument as a list of colors or color palettes:

```{r compare_custom_palettes, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 3}
# Define 2 palettes: 
pal1 <- c(rev(pal_seeblau), "white", pal_bordeaux)
pal2 <- usecol(c(Karpfenblau, Seeblau, "gold"), n = 10)

# Show the mypair palette from above, the 2 palettes just defined, and 2 pre-defined palettes:  
seecol(list(mypair, pal1, pal2, pal_unikn, pal_unikn_pair))
```

Note that unknown palettes will be named `pal`n in increasing order.  Palettes known to `seecol` will be shown with their respective names.  

As before, you can use the `n` argument to use subsets of color palettes: 

```{r subset_compare, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 3}
seecol(list(mypair, pal1, pal2, pal_unikn, pal_unikn_pair), n = 5)
```

or extend color palettes: 

```{r superset_compare, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 3}
seecol(list(mypair, pal1, pal2, pal_unikn, pal_unikn_pair), n = 15)
```
